GeneDef.label: hyper aging fertility shortening
GeneDef.description:
Carriers of this gene have their fertility shortened by a factor of 2.5. This means they will still mostly follow the same curve, but it will take far fewer years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the extension genes, the starting point will not move with the rest of the curve, which means the curve will both start and end later than math would suggest(i.e. shortening by 2 puts male start and ends at 14 and 52 instead of the 7 and 45 the math says based on the normal 14 and 90).

This is intended for xenotypes that have unbelievably short lifespans for whatever reason.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 14
Fertility gain peaks at age 16 for males, and 16 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 28 for males, and 20 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss ends at age 44 for males, and 28 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

This is intended for xenotypes that have super short lifespans for whatever reason.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 14
Fertility gain peaks at age 16 for males, and 17 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively

Unlike the extension genes, the starting point will not move with the rest of the curve, which means the curve will both start and end later than math would suggest(i.e. shortening by 2 puts male start and ends at 14 and 52 instead of the 7 and 45 the math says based on the normal 14 and 90).

GeneDef.description:
Carriers of this gene have their fertility shortened by a factor of 1.1. This means they will still mostly follow the same curve, but it will take far fewer years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the extension genes, the starting point will not move with the rest of the curve, which means the curve will both start and end later than math would suggest(i.e. shortening by 2 puts male start and ends at 14 and 52 instead of the 7 and 45 the math says based on the normal 14 and 90).

This is intended for xenotypes that have shorter lifespans for whatever reason.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 14
Fertility gain peaks at age 18 for males, and 19 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 47 for males, and 27 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss ends at age 83 for males, and 47 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

GeneDef.label: minor aging fertility extension
GeneDef.description:
Carriers of this gene have their fertility elongated by a factor of 1.5. This means they will still follow the same curve, but it will take many more years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the shortening genes, the starting point will move with the rest of the curve.

They will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an extremely long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

If you have More Cell Stability Genes, this would cover the lifespan of a xenotype with super cell stability. Covers the 140%-180% factor range (age easily reaches 112-144 years).

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 21 instead of the normal 14
Fertility gain limit at age 27 for males, and 30 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 75 for males, and 42 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss limit at age 135 for males, and 75 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

GeneDef.label: aging fertility extension
GeneDef.description:
Carriers of this gene have their fertility elongated by a factor of 2. This means they will still follow the same curve, but it will take many more years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the shortening genes, the starting point will move with the rest of the curve.

They will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

If you have Expanded Archite Genes and More Cell Stability Genes, this would cover the lifespan of a xenotype with major archite cell stability. Covers the 200%-250% lifespan factor range (age easily reaches 160-200 years).

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 28 instead of the normal 14
Fertility gain limit at age 36 for males, and 40 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 100 for males, and 56 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss limit at age 180 for males, and 100 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

GeneDef.label: major aging fertility extension
GeneDef.description:
Carriers of this gene have their fertility elongated by a factor of 4. This means they will still follow the same curve, but it will take many more years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the shortening genes, the starting point will move with the rest of the curve.

They will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

This covers xenotypes with a lifespan factor of 400%-500%. A 500% multiplier makes pawns easily live to be 400 years, assuming no other methods are used to prolong life.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 56 instead of the normal 14
Fertility gain limit at age 72 for males, and 80 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 200 for males, and 112 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss limit at age 360 for males, and 200 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

Carriers of this gene have their fertility elongated by a factor of 6. This means they will still follow the same curve, but it will take many more years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the shortening genes, the starting point will move with the rest of the curve.

They will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an extremely long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

This covers xenotypes with a lifespan factor of 600%-700%. A 700% multiplier makes pawns easily live to be 560 years, assuming no other methods are used to prolong life.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 84 instead of the normal 14
Fertility gain limit at age 108 for males, and 120 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 300 for males, and 168 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss limit at age 540 for males, and 300 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

They will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an extremely long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

This covers xenotypes with a lifespan factor of 800%-900%. A 900% multiplier makes pawns easily live to be 720 years, assuming no other methods are used to prolong life.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 112 instead of the normal 14
Fertility gain limit at age 144 for males, and 160 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 400 for males, and 224 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss limit at age 720 for males, and 400 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

GeneDef.label: hyper aging fertility extension
GeneDef.description:
Carriers of this gene have their fertility elongated by a factor of 10. This means they will still follow the same curve, but it will take many more years to reach peaks and lows.

Unlike the shortening genes, the starting point will move with the rest of the curve.

They will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an unbelievably long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

This covers xenotypes with a lifespan factor of 1000% or more. An 1,000% multiplier makes pawns easily live to be 800 years, assuming no other methods are used to prolong life.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility gain begins at age 140 instead of the normal 14
Fertility gain limit at age 180 for males, and 200 for females instead of the normal 18 and 20 respectively
Fertility loss starts at age 500 for males, and 280 for females instead of the normal 50 and 28 respectively
Fertility loss limit at age 900 for males, and 500 for females instead of the normal 90 and 50 respectively

GeneDef.label: always fertile
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene never lose all of their fertility due to the effects of old age.\n\nThey will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an extremely long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Fertility loss due to old age stops at 5%.

GeneDef.label: always very fertile
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene never lose fertility due to the effects of old age.\n\nThey will still lose immunity gain speed due to age at the normal rate, so if this is to be attached to an extremely long lived xenotype, it is recommended to include an immunity gain speed.

customEffectDescriptions.li: Completely stops fertility loss due to old age.
